newsitem.title: BRAZIL: TENNIS-COURIER FIGHTS OFF KUERTEN TO SEE UNITED STATES HOME.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-COURIER FIGHTS OFF KUERTEN TO SEE UNITED STATES HOME.

text.p: Jim Courier fought off a gallant challenge from Gustavo Kuerten to give the United States an unbeatable 3-1 lead over Brazil in their world group first round Davis Cup tie on Sunday.

Courier's 6-3 6-2 5-7 7-6 (13-11) win over Kuerten, a player more than 60 places below him in the world rankings, in the reverse singles finally settled a tie which had all the necessary ingredients for an upset.

The North Americans' inexperienced team had to contend with a partisan crowd and oppressive conditions against opponents who, although fielding a weak team on paper, had not lost a Davis Cup tie at home for 10 years.

The United States had taken a 2-0 lead on Friday but Brazil fought their way back into the tie on Saturday when unrated Jaime Oncins and Kuerten scored a stunning straight sets win over Alex O'Brien and Richey Reneberg.
Courier initially appeared to be heading for an easy win, especially when he won eight games in a row early on, a run which allowed him to win the first set and take a 4-0 lead in the second.
Kuerten had nothing to offer at the start, his sluggishness around the court suggesting he had just come from a large bowl of feijoada, a heavy local stew.

Even the usually boisterous crowd was strangly mute while the informal band that normally plays a quick samba between points turned up half an hour after the start. By then Courier was already on top as he took the first two sets.
But the 20-year-old fought back superbly to break Courier's serve in the 12th game and take the third set 7-5.
With the crowd awake again, Kuerten continued to confront Courier on equal terms in the fourth set, both men playing from the back of the court.
Long, often tedious rallies resulted as both players held their service but the lack of variety was offset by some high drama in the shape of the tie-break which ultimately decided the match.
Kuerten heroically saved four match points, Courier twice volleying into the net, and also held two points to level the rubber at two sets each.
But the American, who needed treatment for dehydration afterwards, finally wrapped up the tie at the fifth attempt.
